SafetyInspectionBy: L&I (State of Washington Labor and Industries)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Facility Name: Monson Fruit Company
Selah, WA 98942
Parent Company: 
RMP Facility ID: 
 
 
RMP Executive Summary below:
 
Monson Fruit Company (hereinafter called "Monson") has a large refrigeration system to quickly chill, pack and store under controlled atmosphere a variety of fruit products.The system has a computerized process control system that monitors system performance and  controls its operation.

Ammonia is used as a refrigerant in this system.  Ammonia is a colorless gas with a pungent odor that is an irritant to the eyes, nose and throat. It is normally shipped as a liquefied compressed gas and is present in portions of the refrigeration system as a liquid under pressure. Please refer to onsite data for ammonia quantities.

In order to protect its employees, the public, and the environment, the Monson facility has an integrated safety management program to prevent ammonia releases and mitigate the consequences of a release, should one occur.  The program is contained in a comprehensive web-based format designed to comply with WISHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM) found in WAC 296-67 and EPA's Risk Management Plan (RMP) regulations found in 40 CFR Part 68. Monson's safety management website is a valuable tool through which Monson will be able to document any changes in safety or emergency procedures immediately upon their adoption.

The Monson plant has an emergency plan that addresses the response necessary for a release of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  Because of the pungent odor of ammonia, any leak is easily detected.  The compressor rooms are provided with ammonia detectors that sound an alarm if ammonia is detected.  The plant refrigeration manager is trained and qualified to respond to leaks of ammonia.  The refrigeration system is designed so that major components can be isolated by closing selected valves.  In case of a release that could travel off the plant property, calls would be made to the Selah police and fire departm

ents and to the Yakima County emergency services to assist in the response. 

During the last five years, there have been no reportable releases of ammonia. Should there be an accidental release when no one was on the premises, this situation would be handled by computer controls.  Ammonia leak detectors are installed and the computer checks all areas where ammonia could possibly be.  When the computer detects ammonia it turns on the alarm and dials emergency numbers for appropriate refrigeration personnel. The employees in turn come down to the warehouse and fix the leak and shut off the alarm.

Monson makes daily inspections of the process to determine if there are any potential problems; in addition, a monthly maintenance program is in place, carried out by Central Washington Refrigeration, the original equipment installer.

As a result of a recently-revalidated Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) of the ammonia refrigeration system,  the compressor room ammonia sensors have been placed on a regular calibration schedule.  Wind socks are installed at various locations so that they can be seen from any outdoor location at the plant.  If a release occurs, this will enable employees to quickly determine the wind direction during a release and to assemble in a pre-designated assembly location.  It will also provide a quick indication of whether the toxic cloud is traveling toward the populated area in Selah.
